content.description: Enuresis is characterized by repeated voiding of urine into bed or clothes, whether involuntary or intentional, occurring at least twice a week for at least three consecutive months or causing clinically significant distress or impairment. The child must be at least 5 years old (or have an equivalent developmental level). Enuresis may occur during sleep (nocturnal), waking hours (diurnal), or both.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Repeated voiding of urine into bed or clothes, whether involuntary or intentional. B. The behavior occurs at least twice a week for at least three consecutive months or causes clinically significant distress or impairment. C. Chronological age is at least 5 years (or equivalent developmental level). D. The behavior is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.
content.prevalence: Occurs in approximately 5â€“10% of 5-year-olds, with rates decreasing to 1% by adolescence. More common in boys.
content.age_of_onset: Diagnosis is made at age 5 or older; primary enuresis is present from birth, while secondary enuresis develops after a period of continence.
content.prognosis: Spontaneous remission rate is about 15% per year. Prognosis is better with early intervention, consistent behavioral strategies, and when secondary causes are addressed.

sleep_arousal_mechanisms: Delayed maturation of arousal pathways between bladder signaling and cortical awakening during sleep.
bladder_function: Reduced functional bladder capacity or overactive detrusor muscle activity during sleep.
hormonal_regulation: Relative nocturnal deficiency of vasopressin (ADH), leading to increased nighttime urine production.
brain_bladder_axis: Possible alterations in central inhibitory control of micturition involving the prefrontal cortex and pontine micturition center.

history: Onset and pattern (primary vs. secondary enuresis).
Daytime urinary symptoms and bowel habits.
physical_exam: Neurological assessment for lower spinal cord signs.
investigations: Urinalysis to rule out infection, diabetes, or kidney disease.
Bladder diary to monitor voiding patterns.

nocturnal_enuresis: Bedwetting during sleep, most often in the first third of the night.

biological: Family history of delayed bladder control.
psychological: Stressful life events (e.g., school changes, family conflict).

preschool: Delayed toilet training may contribute to persistence of wetting.
school_age: Primary enuresis more common; can cause embarrassment and avoidance of sleepovers.
adolescence: Less common; often associated with persistent risk factors or comorbid conditions.

impact_on_life.relationships: May cause shame, avoidance of social events, and peer teasing.
impact_on_life.school: Reluctance to participate in overnight trips or activities.
impact_on_life.self_esteem: Low confidence due to perceived loss of control.

behavioral: Enuresis alarms to condition awakening in response to bladder fullness.
lifestyle_strategies: Limit evening fluid and caffeine intake.

treatment_goals: Address underlying medical or psychological contributors.
warning_signs: New onset after established continence (secondary enuresis).
self_help_strategies: Consistent bedtime routine and toileting before sleep.
real_life_examples: A 7-year-old with primary nocturnal enuresis responds to alarm therapy within 3 months.
A 9-year-old develops secondary enuresis after parental divorce; symptoms improve with counseling and routine restoration.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek professional evaluation if wetting persists beyond age 5, starts suddenly after dryness, or is accompanied by pain, fever, or other urinary symptoms.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Assuming symptoms are purely behavioral without medical assessment.
Failure to screen for sleep apnea in persistent cases.
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling occasional accidents as enuresis before age 5.
Not differentiating between nocturnal and diurnal patterns when planning treatment.
